wp:category.wp:category_description: Learn how to grow your business with our marketing tips.
PPC - Pay per click campaign tips and tricks.
Search Engine Optimization tips on how to get your website ranked higher in search engines.
Build and grow your website with Battle IT Solutions.
Learn how to write compelling content to help grow your brand.
Learn how to write to sell your services and products.
Learn graphic design tips and tricks
Learn about the latest web design tips and tricks.
Learn how to develop a website for your brand.
How to maintain your website and stay up to date.
How to make your website more accessible to users with disabilities.
Learn how to create apps for android devices.
Front end web dev tips and tricks

Develop websites that perform well on mobile devices.

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: bits17
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: bits17
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Our website address is: https://blog.battleitsolutions.com.

What personal data we collect and why we collect it

Comments

When visitors leave comments on the site we collect the data shown in the comments form, and also the visitor’s IP address and browser user agent string to help spam detection.

An anonymized string created from your email address (also called a hash) may be provided to the Gravatar service to see if you are using it. The Gravatar service privacy policy is available here: https://automattic.com/privacy/. After approval of your comment, your profile picture is visible to the public in the context of your comment.

Media

If you upload images to the website, you should avoid uploading images with embedded location data (EXIF GPS) included. Visitors to the website can download and extract any location data from images on the website.

Contact forms

Cookies

If you leave a comment on our site you may opt-in to saving your name, email address and website in cookies. These are for your convenience so that you do not have to fill in your details again when you leave another comment. These cookies will last for one year.

If you visit our login page, we will set a temporary cookie to determine if your browser accepts cookies. This cookie contains no personal data and is discarded when you close your browser.

When you log in, we will also set up several cookies to save your login information and your screen display choices. Login cookies last for two days, and screen options cookies last for a year. If you select "Remember Me", your login will persist for two weeks. If you log out of your account, the login cookies will be removed.

If you edit or publish an article, an additional cookie will be saved in your browser. This cookie includes no personal data and simply indicates the post ID of the article you just edited. It expires after 1 day.

Embedded content from other websites

Articles on this site may include embedded content (e.g. videos, images, articles, etc.). Embedded content from other websites behaves in the exact same way as if the visitor has visited the other website.

These websites may collect data about you, use cookies, embed additional third-party tracking, and monitor your interaction with that embedded content, including tracking your interaction with the embedded content if you have an account and are logged in to that website.

Analytics

Who we share your data with

How long we retain your data

If you leave a comment, the comment and its metadata are retained indefinitely. This is so we can recognize and approve any follow-up comments automatically instead of holding them in a moderation queue.

For users that register on our website (if any), we also store the personal information they provide in their user profile. All users can see, edit, or delete their personal information at any time (except they cannot change their username). Website administrators can also see and edit that information.

What rights you have over your data

If you have an account on this site, or have left comments, you can request to receive an exported file of the personal data we hold about you, including any data you have provided to us. You can also request that we erase any personal data we hold about you. This does not include any data we are obliged to keep for administrative, legal, or security purposes.

Where we send your data

Visitor comments may be checked through an automated spam detection service.

Your contact information

Additional information

How we protect your data

What data breach procedures we have in place

What third parties we receive data from

What automated decision making and/or profiling we do with user data

Industry regulatory disclosure requirements

item.title: How to Install WordPress Self Hosted
item.dc:creator: emmanuelbattle
item.content:encoded:
WordPress.Com vs WordPress.Org
WP.com is hosted by WordPress and WP.org is hosted by anyone of your choice. Check out hosting prices.

WordPress.com started as a blog hosting service but today it is a great way to build simple websites. I recommend getting a wordpress.com account even if you are going to use wp.org because to use plug-ins like jetpack and others you will need a wordpress.com account. WordPress.com is Free for basic needs like writing blog articles. To add additional functionalities to your website you may have to pay. You cannot install plug-ins on WordPress.com websites but you can install free plug-ins with wp.org and even have custom plug-ins created for your website. Lastly, with wordpress.com you will likely have advertisements running on your website unless you pay to have them disabled (You don't get any of the ad revenue either).

With WordPress.org you are not nearly as limited as you are with WordPress.com. Like wordpress.com, WordPress.Org is also free. However, you will need to find a good reliable host and purchase a domain for your website. You can still get started for around $20 or less and have unlimited options as far as the design and functionality of your website. WordPress.org has a huge community of developers that are constantly creating new plug-ins and themes for the platform. You can also make money a lot of different ways using WP.org (ad revenue, e comm, digital courses, membership sites, etc).

In short, if you are a hobbyist, blogger or just want to write articles then wordpress.com is perfect to get started. If you are a business owner or professional in need of a large robust website then you'll need WordPress.org. With that being said, let's get started Installing Wordpress (.org).

Requirements:

  • MySql Version 5.0.15 (5.6 is recommended)
  • PHP version 5.2.4 or higher (7.3 or above is recommended)
  • Website Hosting
  • Domain | Subdomain
  • Server access - Cpanel Access

If Battle I.T. Solutions' your website hosting provider, we will install WordPress automatically at no charge. Call us or text us to save time and we'll install WordPress for you in no time. If not, check with your hosting provider to see if they offer this service.

How to Install WordPress

Option 1- One-Click install (Varies depending on hosting provider)

One-click WordPress install (Record Process)

  1. Access your server's control panel (CPanel) or your hosting provider's control panel.
  2. Locate QuickInstall, One-Click install or Softaculous and open it. (May differ with your hosting provider)
  3. Enter WordPress in the search field and click on its icon.
  4. Now fill in your website information:
    1. URL – Choose the domain you wish to install WordPress on from the dropdown menu. (www.Example.com)
    2. Language – Choose the WordPress language.
    3. Administrator Username – Your WordPress admin username. You will use it to access the WordPress admin area after installation.
    4. Administrator Password – Your WordPress admin password. You will use it to access the WordPress admin area for the first time but will change it later.
    5. Administrator Email – Enter an email address that you would like to receive WordPress notifications on.
    6. Website Title – The title of your WordPress website.(You can change this later)
    7. Website Tagline – A short sentence explaining what your website is about. (You can change this later also)
  5. Press the Install button.
  6. Start configuring WordPress.

Option 2- Install WordPress Manually

  1. Download WordPress. - Click here to get the latest version of WordPress.
  2. Upload Wordpress
    • (Option 1) Upload Using FileZilla (or FTP of your choice)
      1. Download Filezilla
      2. Install Filezilla
      3. Create FTP Account on your web hosting server.
      4. Log into your FTP account with FileZilla by entering the host (ftp.yourwebsite.com), username and password of the FTP account created in the previous step and lastly the FTP port (21). (Some hosting providers have a configuration file to do this automatically.)
      5. Click Quickconnect
      6. Extract the files from the WordPress zip folder. (You should now have a folder entitled "WordPress")
      7. In Filezilla drag & drop the files extracted from the "WordPress" folder you just extracted to public_html on the server.
    • (Option 2) Upload WordPress directly to your server.
      1. Log into your server's control panel (CPanel)
      2. Open File Manager
      3. Upload the zipped WordPress file in the folder "public_html"
      4. Unzip the WordPress file.
      5. Move the files from WordPress folder to public_html.
  3. Create a new MySql database for WordPress
    1. Log into CPanel.
    2. Click on MySQL Databases.
    3. Create a new database. (Will be using this again so copy it down)
    4. create database user- Username & Password (copy this too)
    5. Assign the newly created user to the database.
    6. Give the new user all privileges.
  4. Enter your domain /wp-admin (example.com/wp-admin)
    1. Choose your language.
    2. Enter the database name that you've just created.
    3. Enter the database username & password that you've just created.
    4. Leave the rest as is and click submit.
    5. Click Run the installation.
    6. Enter your website's title.
    7. Enter an Admin username for your website.
    8. Enter a password for the new admin account.
    9. Enter an email address that you would like to get notifications sent to. (New subscribers, new comments, etc)
    10. Click install WordPress.

Now that you have installed WordPress, you will need to configure it for your website needs. We cover this in detail for you in our next post.

Get Started Setting Up WordPress

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Learn how to install WordPress with a step by step guide. Learn how to manually install WordPress with Battle IT Solutions.
how to install wordpress, how to manually install wordpress, wordpress tutorial, wordpress guide, wordpress step by step guide,

item.title: Setting Up WordPress Website
item.dc:creator: emmanuelbattle
item.content:encoded:
Just Installed WordPress...now what?

In this post, I will show you the next steps after installing WordPress. If you are new to WordPress I know it can seem overwhelming but no worries, you are not alone in this journey. I will help you get the most out of your new WordPress website.

If you follow this guide you will be well on your way to having a highly optimized WordPress site. Let's get started.

Update Links | Permalinks

Before you begin writing new posts and adding pages, you first want to make sure your website's link structure is optimized for search engines. It will be much more difficult after your website has become more established with more content.

  1. Go to your WordPress Dashboard
  2. Click settings > permalinks
  3. Choose the "Post name" option (Best for SEO)
  4. Save changes

This will change the URL structure of your blog post to include the post name in the URL. (yourwebsite.com/postname)This will help optimize your website for search engines and give you a clean looking URL. You can use dates as well if you are building a news site or a website that only post about current events but be careful since this can negatively affect your click-through rates (CTR) since users are less likely to click on a post that's a few years old.

Change Date and Time Settings

You will change the timezone to whatever makes the most sense for your site. The date format can be changed to a few different layouts I will show you how to get a layout like this (January 15th, 2020).

  1. Click settings then general.
  2. Change to the correct timezone for you.
  3. Change date format to custom and enter "F JS, Y" - (Without the quotes)

To get a full breakdown of different formatting options, click here.

Change password

Depending on the method that you used to install WordPress there may be a chance your password is compromised. Whether you had us install WordPress for you or you installed it using a 3rd party software, you will need to change your password to ensure there is no unwanted access to your website.

  1. In the dashboard go to Users > All users
  2. Click your username
  3. Scroll down to the New Password section.
  4. Click generate a new password.
  5. You can either use the generated password (recommended) or you can click on it and fill in your own password.
  6. Click the update user button.

Remove unnecessary Themes

Speed is very important for your website's performance (More on that in a later post). So you will need to make sure there are no unnecessary themes taking up space and slowing your website down.

  1. Go to Appearance > Themes
  2. Click on Theme that's not active. (You are unable to delete active WordPress Themes)
  3. Click delete in the bottom right corner
  4. You will be prompted to verify you would like to remove the theme just click ok.

Change favicon, site title & tagline

  1. Go to Appearance > Customize
  2. Click the Site Identity tab
  3. Change Site Title, tagline, and upload favicon.
  4. Click Publish to save your changes.

Delete default content

  1. Go to Posts > All Posts
  2. Select all the posts you would like to remove by clicking the checkbox to the left of it.
  3. Click bulk actions and select move to trash.
  4. Next, click the Apply button.
  5. Go to Pages > All Pages
  6. repeat steps 2-4

Add contact form

  1. Go to Plugins > Add New
  2. Enter WPForms Lite in the search field.
  3. Install & activate the plugin.
  4. Go to WPForms > Add New
  5. Create your form (Drag any field you want to add from the left & drop it into the form on the right)
  6. Click save once you're done.
  7. Now that the form is created go to settings inside the form builder.
  8. Change the notification email if needed.
  9. Now when you create a page that needs to have this form you can click on add form and choose this form in the edit page section. (Image below)

Set up SSL

You don't want google to label your site as not secure. So to avoid this you need an SSL Certificate. This changes your website from HTTP to HTTPS. For most eCommerce websites this is a requirement to take payments online. Most web hosting companies offer this free of charge. If your web hosting company does not offer this then switch to a better company like us or buy an SSL Certificate here.

Once you have your SSL certificate on your domain, you will need to set up WordPress to use SSL and HTTPS protocols.

  1. Install & Activate Really Simple SSL Plugin
  2. Go to settings > SSL
  3. The Plugin will do all the heavy lifting from here.

If this plugin is having a negative effect on your website's performance then leave a comment and we will write a post on setting up SSL/HTTPS manually.

item.title: About us
item.dc:creator: bits17
item.content:encoded:
Who we are

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Cras non scelerisque justo, id scelerisque velit. Cras non scelerisque justo, id scelerisque velit. Aliquam eget ligula libero. Suspendisse ac sollicitudin mi. Quisque ullamcorper fermentum tempus.

Aliquam ornare, lectus eget varius vehicula, velit quam posuere nulla, mattis commodo dolor dolor et mauris. Suspendisse in eros enim. Pellentesque molestie euismod dui. Donec ullamcorper orci pulvinar augue pulvinar, vulputate eleifend metus pharetra. Donec eget posuere velit.

Learn more about
our work methods

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: bits17
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Contact form 1
item.dc:creator: bits17
item.content:encoded:
<label> Your Name (required) [text* your-name] </label>
